hints_html: Matlab stores entries in rows then columns. Therefore A(i,j)=1 would put a 1 in the ith row and jth column.
hints_latex:
Matlab stores entries in rows then columns. Therefore A(i,j)=1 would put
a 1 in the ith row and jth column.
hints_raw: Matlab stores entries in rows then columns.  Therefore A(i,j)=1 would put a 1 in the ith row and jth column.
question: A 07
sols_html:
From the hint we know that Matlab stores by row then by column. Therefore the first line of code

 A=zeros(3,2);

would create a matrix of zeros with 3 rows and 2 columns,

\[\begin{aligned} A=\begin{bmatrix} 0 & 0\\ 0 & 0\\ 0 & 0 \end{bmatrix}.\end{aligned}\]

The next lines of code

 A(1,1)=5;
 A(2,2)=3;
 A(3,1)=1;

would put a 5 in the 1st row, 1st column, a 3 in the 2nd row, 2nd column and a 1 in the 3rd row, 1st column and therefore,

\[\begin{aligned} A=\begin{bmatrix} 5 & 0\\ 0 & 3\\ 1 & 0 \end{bmatrix}\end{aligned}\]

is our created matrix.
statement_html:
Write the matrix A that would result from the following lines of MATLAB code:

A = zeros(3,2);
A(1,1) = 5;
A(2,2) = 3;
A(3,1) = 1;
